--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Wed, 26 May 2004 14:35:43 -0700 (PDT), Mitchell Timin
> <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> > > Anyway, I think most interesting domains assume
> > > their cost mostly
> > > from domain simulation and not network activation.
> > 
> > It's probably true that for most applications, the
> > application-specific code probably takes longer than
> > processing the NEAT net, but we can't be sure that's
> > true until someone measures the latter.
> 
> I'm not sure I'd generalize this to "most" domains.  If you're
> simulating a 3D environment and doing real-time robot control, this
> might hold true.
> 
> But in a difficult board game domain, like Go, the environment is
> computationally trivial (representing the board state, checking for
> legal moves, etc.), so the vast majority of computation will be in
> network activation.
> 

That's a good point but one exception is if you are evolving against 
another AI program (as I did), such as Gnugo.  Then Gnugo takes up 
most of the processing.  

ken
